narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: good
very applicable to outside research
Good course overall. The instructor can pay more attention to the slides.
good, homeworks should be worth 20%
I think that Dr. Makuch knows a lot about the topic of clinical trials, but I don't feel like I learned a lot in the class.

The course is horrible. Taught poorly Put weight on issues not related to the title of the course. In improvement I think you should find someone interested to teach the course and ensure that if you call a course Fundamentals of clincal trials then that is what it is. The way it is been taught you should call it Statistics in clinical trials to fit its current syllabus

I think that this class has the potential to teach a lot and be useful, but the execution doesn't live up to the promise. It would benefit form more enforced structure -- it usually feels like you talk about whatever Dr. Makuch feels like talking about in a given day instead of a concept that fits into an overarching plan. The readings, homework, and lectures are also not very cohesive.
Useful for anyone interested in regulatory affairs. Useful practical information.

It's a good course with a lot of interesting material. However, I thought the readings were a tad overwhelming, and a lot of students simply stopped doing them as a result. I think I would have enjoyed the class more if the readings were less dense and more concise.
good
strengths: great material, obviously informed professor Weaknesses: Didn't quite grasp concepts. could have gotten a lot more out of it
Perfect.I can't find a more suitable course for me like this in YSPH. Hope the course will keep current format and content.
Strength: great introduction course to clinical trials
useful knowledge for clinical trials

Strength: 1. Well-organized lectures 2. Helpful homework solutions 3. Open-note, open-internet exams make the midterm/final easy Weakness: Some overlapping knowledge with the other course Regulatory Affairs
Strength: open learning, engaging class, casual dialogue Weakness: no depth of learning
This course provides helpful insights on common issues in clinical trials, covering both theoretical and empirical topics.

The class introduced me to the world of clinical trials, which I had little/no prior experience with. Although Professor Makuch has much experience working in this field, his slides are sometimes disorganized and he would go off on tangents. The homework assignments, midterm/final exams may not correlate with the material taught in class. Although everything was open-notes, I found the course sometimes frustrating because of the discrepancy between course material and assignments/exams. The guest speakers were generally great.
very useful in knowing the process of clinical trials
Excellent!
Very good

Good course to give you foundations of clinical trials - easier than most biostats courses I've taken. I like how the professor does exams as open note, open laptop and encourages learning how to do something instead of memorizing equations. Sometimes the slides he uses could have more details or be connected better. It was always a bit difficult to do the homework because the slides didn't have enough information and the book is a bit dense.
Real life examples are very informative, including guest lectures
Good introductory course to clinical trials, but there is a lot of room for improvement in terms of how the materials were taught in the lectures.
Remove homework requirement. Simply suggest it as part of the reading. Otherwise the course was great. It would also be great to have a speaker from the FDA do a visit lecture.
Makuch is a wonderful teacher. However, the lectures are extremely disorganized and do not teach students.
Everything in the exam were asked in homework and the solutions were provided. All important knowledge points were addressed in details on class.
very very poor course do not take it!!!
Excellent. Would be great to use more real examples

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?

Instructor: Robert Makuch  very helpful and accessible for any questions regarding course material
Instructor: Robert Makuch  very knowledgeable but needs to be a bit more clear with expectations; offers better explanations one on one
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He should show more empathy and stop portraying a picture of simplicity on complex stuff.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very easy going and clear instructor.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Really knows what he's talking about, but doesn't hold his own office hours, so I thought it was pretty hard to get in touch with him sometimes. He holds office hours before exams which is always helpful, but I wish he had them more often.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Experienced professor in this field
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very charming and helpful instructor! Open-minded and understanding.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Overall, I think it is necessary to take this class if you are interested in how to conduct the clinical trials in a scientific way.
good
this course is really helpful to get the foundation for clinical trials and understand the concepts that are necessary to conduct clinical trials in a medical/professional context
It is a great introductory course that includes many aspects of clinical trials. Recommend to the student who want to learn clinical trials from scratch.
You learn a lot but seems disorganized and some test questions seem very obscure.
I will not recommend the course to my worst enemy the way it is now
This class is not as interesting or as useful as it sounds. That being said, it is fairly easy and may help reinforce some basic biostatistics concepts.
Useful for anyone interested in regulatory affairs. Useful practical information.
A very interesting class about clinical trials, but be prepared for very dense reading that a lot of people don't really do.
Yes, easy for students from other departments
good baseline knowledge
Highly recommended to everyone.
It gives a great introduction on clinical trials. Must take if looking at future career in pharmaceutical industry.
I would recommend this course to students at YSPH.

Would recommend it Biggest reasons: 1. Light workload 2. Required course for Regulatory Affairs Track 3. Charming instructor Biggest weakness: Overlapping knowledge on some of the lectures with Regulatory Affairs
An introduction to clinical trials suitable for beginners with various backgrounds. I would recommend it to students who are interested or who need to get started in related fields.

The class introduced me to the world of clinical trials, which I had little/no prior experience with. Although Professor Makuch has much experience working in this field, his slides are sometimes disorganized and he would go off on tangents. The homework assignments, midterm/final exams may not correlate with the material taught in class. Although everything is open-notes, I found the course sometimes frustrating because of the discrepancy between course material and assignments/exams. The guest speakers were generally great. I took this class because I needed a biostatistics elective.
yes, very useful
Yes, I'd like to recommend this course to others. It's very helpful!
Yes

Very interesting. Definitely, reccomend.

I really enjoyed the course. I would recommend this course to anyone interested in clinical trials research.

pathetic poor do not take it!
